Q: cout vs. fprintf vs. fputs A:

This is a guard from nonnumerical input. It works, test it :)

Q: MongoSocketOpenException on startup A:

The problem is clear from the logs. Look at the clusterSettings

clusterSettings={hosts=[localhost:27017], srvServiceName=mongodb, mode=SINGLE, ...}

Your mongodb+srv:// URI is being completely ignored. It's falling back to the default localhost:27017.

You may check if your application.properties is on the right path src/main/resources/

You can also check the path if you have application.yml

spring:
     data:
       mongodb:
         uri: mongodb+srv://MYUSERNAME:MYPW@MYPROJECTclu.zgsjafi.mongodb.net/?appName=MYCLUSTER

or check if you have a @Bean for MongoClient or MongoClientSettings somewhere that ignores the property.

Q: Redux Toolkit, when to use createListenerMiddleware over createAsyncThunk A:

@markerikson should also mentioned the play/pause and observable functionality of these Listeners.

https://redux.js.org/usage/side-effects-approaches#listeners

They also receive a listenerApi object with several primitives for building async workflows, such as:

  • condition(): pauses until a certain action is dispatched or state change occurs

  • cancelActiveListeners(): cancel existing in-progress instances of the effect

  • fork(): creates a "child task" that can do additional work

These primitives allow listeners to replicate almost all of the effects behaviors from Redux-Saga.

I believe the following is same person Redux author comment @markerikson

https://www.reddit.com/r/reactjs/comments/15eoagd/comment/ju9htlb/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=web3x&utm_name=web3xcss&utm_term=1&utm_content=share_button

Additionally, listeners have access to a bunch of additional capabilities for async workflow behavior that thunks don't have, like "pause until some condition happens", "cancel running instances", etc.

Q: Is it okay to use a synchronous decorator on a FastAPI route? A:

Yes, it's Ok to use such decorators.

This use-case is covered by tests in FastAPI repo: https://github.com/fastapi/fastapi/blob/6513d4daa16a536d17743de6a292f49bd06388a4/tests/test_dependency_wrapped.py#L183-L200

Q: Does a tightly locked 'while loop' block the GIL? A:

A loop per se will not surrender the GIL. However, assuming that write_queue is an instance of queue.Queue or a subclass, when you call get() the thread will block until there is an element to take from the queue. In the process this will release the GIL and allow another thread to be scheduled.

Note: there is no such thing as a "tightly locked loop". I think you meant to say "tight loop" or "polling loop" ... except that your code isn't even an example of that because get() will block if the queue is empty. Now if you called get(block=False) or get_nowait(), this would be a polling loop.

For more information, read https://docs.python.org/3/library/queue.html

Q: translation of f# expression to c# in the debugger A:

C# doesn't understand normal f# function as @Richard mentioned. Such type argument should be convertend to Func type.

This works:

open System

let wrapListMap<'t, 's> (mapper: Func<'t, 's>, tist: 't list) : 's list =
    tist |> List.map (fun a -> mapper.Invoke a)

let f t = t + 1
let a = [ 0; 1 ]
let b = wrapListMap (f, a)

It is possible now to call in the debugger:

Program.wrapListMap (Program.f, a)
